awd_titl_txt: RUI: Development of Dianionic Enolates for the Stereoselective Synthesis of Natural and Unnatural Amino Acids
awd_abstract_narration:
With this Award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Jeffrey Cannon at Occidental College who works with undergraduate researchers to synthesize unnatural amino acids. Amino acids are one of the fundamental building-blocks of biological systems. Professor Cannon and his research team are devising new strategies for the synthesis of these building blocks that can provide useful quantities of amino acids that are not readily isolated from natural sources. Furthermore, because their three-dimensional shape or stereochemistry is critical for proper function, this research is working to control the exact arrangement of atoms in the amino acid products so that the products function properly in biological systems. Professor Cannon and his research team then apply these results to the chemical synthesis of a family of molecules known as indolizidines. The indolizidine structure is found in many biologically-active molecules.  Molecules of this type have many applications as pharmaceuticals and other biological agents. The broader impacts include new syntheses and applications of unnatural amino acids as well as the development of biologically-active nitrogen-containing molecules. This project also creates summer research fellowships for undergraduates in synthetic chemistry with an emphasis on support for underrepresented students.

There are many limitations to the syntheses of unnatural amino acids, especially those that are fully-substituted. Professor Cannon and his students are developing the reactions of dianionic enolates to provide ready stereoselective access to unnatural amino acid derivatives and other synthetic precursors. His research group is investigating the use of a chiral auxiliary to direct the stereochemistry of reactions of dianionic enolates. These reactions are studied experimentally as well as computationally in order to understand the elements of control provided by these auxiliaries. The goal is to provide a robust and accessible system for the synthesis of amino acids. These reactions are tested in complex settings in order to understand their limitations and inspire further reaction development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This Research at an Undergraduate Institution award was to support projects in the use of dianionic enolate reagents in the stereoselective synthesis of small organic molecules of biological relevance. Stereoselectivity, or the selection of one isomer of a specific three-dimensional shape, is critical for the development of effective medicines and other biologically active molecules. This project focused on the production of amino acids and indolzidine alkaloids. The work conducted under this award was performed almost entirely by undergraduate researchers, and these students gained general training in conducting chemical research, including technical skills as well as broad problem solving abilities.

Intellectual Merit

The projects funded by this award specifically investigated the synthesis of unnatural amino acids, amino ketones, and indolizidine alkaloids. Three specific projects were investigated: 1) the functionalization of alpha-sulfinamido enolates in substitution reactions; 2) the development of an auxiliary-directed Ireland–Claisen rearrangement; and 3) a generalized enantioselective synthesis of indolizidine alkaloids.

In the first project, methods for the reactions of alpha-sulfinamido enolates for both aldol and alkylation reactions were discovered and developed. A new, stereoselective aldol reaction was studied and developed. This new reaction can provide increasingly complex molecules with good levels of control. This process was also expanded to the alkylation of ketones, which presented an additional challenge of regioselectivity.

In the second project, a new diastereoselective Ireland–Claisen reaction was discovered that used a novel chiral auxiliary to make stereochemically pure products. This reaction provides a new route to complex and enantiopure amino acids for the use in bioengineering and small molecule synthesis research. The study of this reaction provided insights into the modes of stereoselection that can improve on future Ireland–Claisen rearrangements.

The third project targeted indolizidine alkaloids, which are an alkaloid substructure that makes up a large proportion of biologically active natural products. Utilizing a combined Ireland–Claisen and ring-closing metathesis process, an enantiomerically pure indolizidine alkaloid core was prepared. This core structure can be functionalized at all positions. This strategy provided a unified method to a diverse library of indolizidine molecules.

Broader Impacts

A central goal of this research was to support the training of undergraduate students in chemical research projects. These projects proved to be excellent training grounds for students to develop technical and problem-solving skills. This award supported 19 undergraduates and 2 high school students both directly and indirectly as they produced the experimental results that support the research projects. Many of these students had the opportunity to present their research at national conferences such as the National Organic Chemistry Symposium and the American Chemical Society national meeting. All students who were involved in this project are either pursuing advanced degrees in chemistry, medical school, or are employed in the chemical industry.


Last Modified: 12/12/2024
Modified by: Jeffrey Cannon
